The documents state that the first capital of the Bahmani Sultanate was Gulbarga. While Bidar later became a capital of the Bahmani Sultanate, it was not the original one.

mistral.reason: The capital of the Bahmani Sultanate was not Bidar, but Gulbarga. Bidar was a major center of Islamic culture and learning during the Bahmani Sultanate, but it was only the capital from 1422 to 1527. The original capital was Gulbarga.

gemma2.reason: Several texts state that the first capital of the Bahmani Sultanate was Gulbarga, not Bidar. Additionally, Bidar became a capital later, from 1422 to 1527, under Ahmed Shah Wali Bahmani.

llama3.1.reason: It was mentioned in option B) that Bidar was the capital of the Bahmani Sultanate, but it was not the first capital.  It was the capital from 1422 to 1527, implying that there were other capitals before and after this period, suggesting that Bidar was not the initial or sole capital of the Bahmani Sultanate.

qwen2.5.reason: Bidar was not the first capital of the Bahmani Sultanate. According to the context, Bidar became the capital in 1422, succeeding another capital. The correct sequence is that Gulbarga was the first capital from 1347 to 1422, followed by Bidar until 1527, and then Bijapur from 1527 to 1619.
